item.question:
You started the program rups in the background and you notice it consumes a lot of resources.
Which of the following commands can you use to make the command you just started use less CPU resources?
item.hint: The question is about changing the priority of a RUNNING proces. Changing the priority is done by changing the nice value of the proces. A lower value means less nice, a higher value means the proces is nicer to other processes regarding CPU resources.

item.question:
To list the PIDs of running applications which commands can NOT be used?
(Select all correct answers)
item.hint: Beware that sometimes the question asks for the opposite. In this case commands that DO NOT list the PIDs.

item.question:
Which of the following commandlines allows you to see the difference between the content of
the tar archive and the current content of the directory /home?
item.hint: Even if you never used <font face="monospace">tar</font> in this way you may be able to answer this question correctly by eliminating the wrong answers.

item.question:
You are a regular user (not root) and want to examine the PCI bus configuration.
Which command can you use?
item.choice: None of the mentioned choices, it is only possible with <font face="monospace">root</font>-privileges.
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: What is the maximum amount of devices, not including the host adapter, you can connect to an 8 bit SCSI card?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: Which command can you use to create a link (<font face="monospace">newdir</font>) to an existing directory (<font face="monospace">existingdir</font>) on the same filesystem?
item.hint: Read the question carefully. It asks for creating a link to a DIRECTORY. Besides the order of the existing dir and the link you will need to know the limitations of creating a hard- and softlink to answer this question correctly.

item.question: If you want to change the default runlevel on a RedHat system to start a graphical login which line would you use in <font face="monospace">/etc/inittab</font>?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: Which command would give you a listing of the contents of a tar archive?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: You want to repeat the last command that began with the letters 'mo'. How would you do this?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: The kernelfile vmlinuz-2.6.18 is in the ________ directory.
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer. Note that the question does not explicitly state you should provide the absolute path as well. Your safest bet is to provide the absolute path.

item.question:
Suppose user pete has created a new application atop, and copied it to the directory /usr/local/bin.
On your system each user belongs to his/her own unique group.
For instance, user petra belongs to the group petra and pete belongs to the group pete.
You would like all the users who do not belong to the group and are not owner of the application to be able to run your application.
Which of the following command lines would allow the appropriate access?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
You are editing the file foo with vi.
You want to save the changes with '[ESC]:w', but vi complains you do not have sufficient rights.
Therefore, you want to check the permissions on that file.
How do you manage this without leaving vi?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
You just got a new disk and want to make it accessible for users.
Which command(s) do you require to perform this task?
Select all that apply.
item.hint: The question is about setting up a fresh new harddisk for general usage on a Linux system. You should select all commands you will need to accomplish the task.

item.question:
You downloaded a compressed file and want to display the contents (filenames) before extracting it.
The name of the downloaded file is stableos.tar.bz2.
Which single command (no options) can you use?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
When you wish to install a new application you downloaded from the internet what would be a good location on the filesystem according to the Filesystem Hierarchy Standard.
Assume that you want other users to be able to use the application as well.
item.hint: The question mentions a new application downloaded from the internet. It does not mention the format of the application, so you may assume that it is not a package from your linux distribution.

item.question: Which of the following commands can be used to create a tar archive file?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: Which run level represents a power down?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: What is the meaning of setting the sticky bit permission on a directory?
item.choice: all files created in the directory will belong to the same group as the directory.
files and directories can only be deleted by their owner
it can be used to temporarily lock the directory
files and directories can only be deleted by their owner, the owner of the directory, or a user with root privileges.
item.correct_answer: files and directories can only be deleted by their owner, the owner of the directory, or a user with root privileges.
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
You want to find the location on the filesystem of the command you previously executed.
Which command would you use?
item.hint: This question is about how Bash finds commands on the filesystem to execute not where a file with a certain name can be found on the filesystem.

item.question:
You need to display all files in the current directory that start with at and end with a g.
Choose the best answer.
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
You execute the above command.
You now want to know which echo command was executed.
Which command is best fit for the job?
item.hint: When it is not stated explicitly which shell is used assume the Bash shell.

item.question: Which file is the main configuration file for the init process?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: Which of the following commands gets its input from <font face="monospace">file1</font>, writes its output to <font face="monospace">file2</font> and writes errormessages to <font face="monospace">file3</font>?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
Which of the following command lines can (possibly) be used to format a partition?
Assume that logical partitioning is used on each hard-disk.
item.hint: The question does not state anything about the filesystem type. Although you see <font face="monospace">ext2</font> and <font face="monospace">msdos</font> as possible filesystem types you can disregard this information and both may be correct.

item.question: What will be the result of the above command?
item.choice: Changes directory to the user guru0's home directory
Changes to a directory named <font face="monospace">~guru0</font>
Changes to directory named <font face="monospace">guru0</font> in the current directory
item.correct_answer: Changes directory to the user guru0's home directory
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: Which condition(s) must be true if two directories each require their own quotum for filesystem usage?
item.choice: They must exist on Ext3 partitions
The directories must have the setgid permission set.
They must be on different partitions
They must be mounted by the root user
item.correct_answer: They must be on different partitions

item.question: Which of the following commands will print the usage of each mounted filesystem?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: Which command will show the number of free and used inodes for your system's mounted file systems?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: Which option can be used with the shutdown command that will not shutdown the system but will send the warning message that the system will shutdown.
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
You issue the above command with root-privileges.
What will happen to your system?
item.choice: Your system will make eating sounds (yum, yum)
Your debian system will be upgraded to the new stable version
Your redhat system will be upgraded to the new release version
Packages already installed will be updated if a new version is available
item.correct_answer: Packages already installed will be updated if a new version is available
item.hint: Usually you use <font face="monospace">yum upgrade</font> to upgrade the system to a new version but this requires more actions than are mentioned in the question.

item.question: Given the above exhibit, which command could you use to bring application 'vi' to the foreground?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: In which directory would you look to see if a USB device was correctly detected by the kernel?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: Which command will show the first 10 lines of a file by default?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
At the commandline you set a variable's value with the command export MYVAR=hello.
Afterwards you execute the above script.
When the script finishes you type the command echo $MYVAR.
What would be the output of the last command you executed?
item.hint: The script is started by a child proces. Therefore the variable <font face="monospace">MYVAR</font> in the script is set in the child proces and will be lost when the script finishes.

item.question: Which run level(s) can be used as administration mode?
item.hint: Any runlevel that allows you to log in can be used to administer the system.

item.question: Which option can be used with the shutdown command to <font face="monospace">fsck</font> on the next reboot?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
Consider the above exhibit.
What would best describe the rm command at the end?
item.choice: It will remove the symbolic link <font face="monospace">desiree</font> and the contents of the file potato
It will remove the symbolic link <font face="monospace">desiree</font> as well as the symbolic link <font face="monospace">fries</font>
It will remove the symbolic link <font face="monospace">desiree</font>
It will remove the symbolic link <font face="monospace">desiree</font> and relink the symbolic link <font face="monospace">fries</font> to <font face="monospace">potato</font>
item.correct_answer: It will remove the symbolic link <font face="monospace">desiree</font>
item.hint: Symbolic links are files that contain a directory path and filename to the file they are pointing to.

item.question:
You are looking for the string MyString (not mystring) in the file foo.
Which of the following commands can you use?
Select all answers that apply.
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: Which command can be used to make init reload its configuration file?
item.hint: Although nowadays there are multiple versions of init used (e.g. <font face="monospace">systemd</font>, <font face="monospace">upstart</font>), if the question does not state a particular version explicitly assume the question is about the System V init system.

item.question:
Which of the following commandlines can you use in a BASH shell to make sure the command started in the shell uses the configuration-file top.conf.
Select two.
item.hint: You will need to provide exactly two correct answers. Note that defining a variable and using a variable requires a different syntax. Also note that the question mentions commands started in the shell should be able to read the variable. Hence, the shell should pass the variable to its childs.

item.question:
Which of the following items are specified in the file /etc/fstab.
Choose all correct answers.
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
Which of the following will copy the text-file file1 to file2?
Choose all correct answers.
item.hint: Note that the question is about copying a TEXT file and not a binary file.

item.question:
Which command would find only the program file atop, it's configuration files, it's manual pages, and source files?
Choose all that apply.
item.hint: The question is not about any file that contains the text <font face="monospace">atop</font> but specific kind of files that belong to the program <font face="monospace">atop</font>.

item.question: What will the command kill -HUP 134 most likely do?
item.choice: Restart the process 134, re-reading it's config files
Give the process a new process number.
item.correct_answer: Restart the process 134, re-reading it's config files
item.hint: As the question does not say what <font face="monospace">134</font> is you need to know what sending the signal <font face="monospace">HUP</font> will do in general.

item.question: What best describes the above commandline when executed?
item.choice: <font face="monospace">cat</font> reads from the file <font face="monospace">/etc/passwd</font> through stdin and pipes the output to <font face="monospace">grep</font>
<font face="monospace">cat</font> reads the files <font face="monospace"><</font> and <font face="monospace">/etc/passwd</font> and sends the output to <font face="monospace">grep</font>
No output as <font face="monospace">guru1</font> is not a valid username
item.correct_answer: <font face="monospace">cat</font> reads from the file <font face="monospace">/etc/passwd</font> through stdin and pipes the output to <font face="monospace">grep</font>
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: Considering the command <font face="monospace">dpkg</font> which of the following options are correct?
item.choice: <font face="monospace">-C</font> searches for packages partially installed on the system
item.correct_answer: <font face="monospace">-C</font> searches for packages partially installed on the system
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: According to the Filesystem Hierarchy Standard (FHS), in which directory (full path name) should you look for system logfiles?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
The user guru1 complains that he cannot access his homedirectory.
Given the directory /home/guru1 has the above permissions.
Which of the following commands would fix this problem?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
You have downloaded an archive called atop.tgz.
Which command could you use to verify the checksum of the file?
item.hint: Although the question does not mention the actual checksum used on the file you should be able to answer the question correctly by eliminating all non-existing commands on a standard Linux system.

item.question: Which command will send the <font face="monospace">HUP</font>-signal to the webserver-process <font face="monospace">httpd</font> (process id 2384) causing it to re-read its configuration?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
In above exhibit first the original text is shown and second the output is shown from COMMAND.
Which of the following commandlines can be used in place of COMMAND to generate the shown output?
Select all correct answers.
item.hint: The order in which the file is sorted is not numerically but alphabetically.

item.question:
Consider the above exhibit.
As you can see bar is a symbolic link, pointing to foo.
As user guru1 you execute 'rm bar'.
What happens?
item.choice: Nothing, because <font face="monospace">bar</font> is no ordinary file.
Both <font face="monospace">foo</font> and <font face="monospace">bar</font> would be removed.
Only <font face="monospace">foo</font> would be removed, because <font face="monospace">bar</font> points to <font face="monospace">foo</font>.
You would be asked whether <font face="monospace">bar</font> or <font face="monospace">foo</font> should be removed.
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
When you create a new directory, you see the permissions are set to rwx--x---.
Which umask value would cause this to happen?
item.hint: When creating a directory the command <font face="monospace">mkdir</font> asks for a certain set of permissions and <font face="monospace">umask</font> is used to determine what the directory will eventually get. In general, the permissions asked when creating a directory are different from when creating a new file.

item.question: What is the result of the above command?
item.choice: You will get the shell secondary prompt
The text echo ATcomputing will be printed
item.correct_answer: You will get the shell secondary prompt
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
You installed a new set of shared libraries in /usr/local/mynewlib.
You run the command ldconfig.
However, running the application still causes problems, complaining it cannot find the shared libraries.
What is most likely the cause of this?
item.choice: You forgot to enter the library path in <font face="monospace">ld.so.conf</font>.
When you install new libraries, you need to recompile or re-install the application.
You forgot to add the library path to the <font face="monospace">PATH</font> variable.
You forgot to reboot the system (the libraries are discovered at kernel initialization).
item.correct_answer: You forgot to enter the library path in <font face="monospace">ld.so.conf</font>.
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
You want to remove a package from the system completely, including its configuration files.
Which dpkg command-option(s) should you use?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: Is it possible for a regular user to mount and unmount a filesystem?
item.choice: There is no way a regular user can do this, because it is a root privilege.
Yes, if the option '<font face="monospace">user</font>' is added to the corresponding line in <font face="monospace">/etc/fstab</font>.
Yes, if the option '<font face="monospace">allusers</font>' is added to the corresponding line in <font face="monospace">/etc/fstab</font>.
Yes, any user can mount and unmount filesystems.
item.correct_answer: Yes, if the option '<font face="monospace">user</font>' is added to the corresponding line in <font face="monospace">/etc/fstab</font>.
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: On a Debian system, which file should be edited to add an extra location from which installation package files can be loaded?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
You want to know how much disk-space you are using in your homedirectory.
Which of the following commands will accomplish this?
item.hint: The question does not state what your current working directory is. Hence, the remark that you want to know the disk-space in your homedirectory allows you to easily eliminate to possible answers.

item.question:
You are working on a Debian system and you made a mess of the samba configuration file.
Unfortunately you forgot to create a backup of the configuration file.
Which of the following would allow you to make a fresh start with the initial samba configuration from the debian samba package?
item.choice: It is not possible without reinstalling samba.
